sn55.6:2.2: “My good man, let us know when you see the Blessed One coming, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
sn55.6:2.3: And that person stood there for two or three days before they saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.

sn55.6:14.1: “Well then, chamberlains, living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
sn55.6:14.2: Just this much is enough to be diligent.”
sn55.6:14.3: “Sir, for us there is something that’s even more cramped than that, and is considered as such.”
sn55.6:15.1: “Sir, it’s when King Pasenadi of Kosala wants to go and visit a park. We have to harness and prepare his royal elephants. Then we have to seat his dear and beloved wives on the elephants, one in front of us, and one behind.
sn55.6:15.2: Those sisters smell like a freshly opened perfume box; that’s how the royal ladies smell with makeup on.
sn55.6:15.3: The touch of those sisters is like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok; that’s how dainty the royal ladies are.
sn55.6:15.4: Now at that time we must look after the elephants, the sisters, and ourselves.
sn55.6:15.5: But we don’t recall having a bad thought regarding those sisters.
sn55.6:15.6: This is that thing that’s even more cramped than that, and is considered as such.”

sn55.6:17.2: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.6:17.6: They live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
sn55.6:17.7: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.
